Description (in brief): Solar radiation dataset consisting of the average irradiance over a time period, taking into account both day and night-time, measured in W/m2. Optimum angle data sets are measured in degrees from horizontal for a plane facing the equator.
Methodology (brief description): The first step in the calculation is to use the satellite images to estimate the influence of clouds on the solar radiation. Clouds tend to reflect the incoming sunlight so that less radiation arrives at the ground. In a second step the method calculates the solar radiation at clear sky conditions (i.e. no clouds) using the theory of radiative transfer in the atmosphere together with data on how much aerosols (dust, particles, etc.) there are in the atmosphere and the concentration of water vapour and ozone, both of which tend to absorb radiation at particular wavelengths. The total radiation is then calculated from the cloud albedo and the clear-sky irradiance. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Accuracy: Data produced from the satellite images were checked against measurements at ground level: -14.0% to +11.0% difference between satellite and station.
Completeness: Data derived from METEOSAT (https://meteostat.net/en) images which cover entirety of Europe.
Creator: Climate Monitoring Satellite Application Facility (CM SAF)
Content (keywords): Solar radiation data - average irradiation - satellite data
Origin: METEOSAT satellite data and reanalysis-based solar radiation data from ECMWF ERA-5 and COSMO-REA.

Description (in brief): Dataset of worldwide geothermal power plants including technological details (e.g. nameplate and running capacity, turbine type).
Methodology (brief description): The dataset contains all geothermal power plants that are in operation. Data are collected from various sources and then validated against 3 other datasets. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Accuracy: Comparison of total installed capacity versus similar datasets: 0.3% difference vs Platts; 1.3% difference vs Think Geoenergy; 9.6% difference vs World Resources Institute (WRI).
Completeness: NULL values in 28.2% of cells, though most columns complete (lat/long, year, name, gross cap).
Creator: Andreas Uihle, Joint Research Centre
Time references (time data refers): Region-specific data sources range from 2010 to 2018
Origin: Data for Europe was mainly from the European Geothermal Energy Council (EGEC). Locations of power plants was manually retrieved. Information about the geothermal areas was adopted from the list of geothermal areas of OpenEI.

Description (in brief): Dataset of European hydro plants with basic information on all the European hydro-power plants.
Methodology (brief description): The database has been built collecting the information from several other sources and then cross-checking and comparing in case of inconsistencies. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Accuracy: Joint Research Centre (JRC) dataset: 1248 unique power plants, World Resources Institute (WRI) dataset: 1918 unique power plants
Completeness: Blank values in 41.4% of cells, though most columns complete (lat/long, year, id, name, installed capacity)
Creator: Matteo De Felice, Joint Research Centre, Konstantinos Kavvadias (Joint Research Centre)
Content (keywords): Hydropower energy - system power - power plants

Description (in brief): The Open Power Plants database contains locations of European power plants.
Methodology (brief description): The linkage of available open sources (ENTSO-E, E-PRTR and other power plant databases) enabled the estimation of several performance parameters for a large part of the listed power plants. These are based on analysis of the generation time series provided in ENTSO-E's Transparency Platform, the CO_ emissions published by the European Environmental Agency's E-PRTR database, as well as the country specific carbon intensity of fuels in each country, published by the UNFCCC. For further information, see the methodology documentation
Accuracy: Joint Research Centre (JRC) dataset: 809 unique power plants, World Resources Institute (WRI) dataset: 2202 unique power plants
Completeness: Blank values in 53.5% of cells and in 75% of lat/long columns (mainly Italy and Spain).
Creator: Hidalgo Gonzalez, Ignacio; Kanellopoulos, Konstantinos; De Felice, Matteo; Bocin, Andrei (Joint Research Centre)
Origin: Joint Research Centre (JRC) Open Power Plants Database (JRC-PPDB-OPEN)

Title (with Hyperlink): EEA: Share of gross final consumption of renewable energy sources
Description (in brief): Approximated estimates for the share of gross final consumption of all renewable energy sources.
Methodology (brief description): The method used by the European Environment Agency (EEA) features a bottom-up calculation, including hundreds of calculations per Member State, using driving data to estimate GHG emissions. Most of the mathematical methods developed for this purpose can be abstracted from GHG calculations and adapted to estimated energy data. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Completeness: Dataset has no blank/missing values.
Creator: European Topic Centre for Air Pollution and Climate Change Mitigation
Object: Approximated estimates for the share of gross final consumption of renewable energy sources in 2017 (EEA 2017 RES share proxies)
License: European Environmental Agency (EEA) standard re-use policy
Other relevant information: For further information on use of dataset please visit https://www.eea.europa.eu/legal/copyright

Description (in brief): Share of final energy consumption in the residential sector by type of end-use.
Methodology (brief description): Energy consumption in households can be caclulated using a variety of methods, principally: business surveys, households surveys, administrative data, or modelling techniques. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Accuracy: "The accuracy of the basic data depends on the quality of the national statistical systems and may vary from country to country."
Completeness: Missing values in 37.0% of cells.
Creator: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Publisher: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Content (keywords): Residential sector -  final energy consumption - gross inland energy consumption

Title (with Hyperlink): Actual Electricity Generation per Production Type
Description (in brief): Actual aggregated net generation output (MW) per market time unit and per production type.
Level: EU27 + UK, Switzerland, Turkey, Serbia, Maldova, Albania, Belarus, Norway, North Macedonia, Montenegro
Creator: European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity (ENTSO-E)

Description (in brief): GEOSTAT 1km2 population grid containing population estimates per 1km x 1km grid cell.
Methodology (brief description): EU Member States use different methods that they consider to be best suited to the administrative practices and traditions of their country. The EU then uses an output-oriented harmonisation of the collected data. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Accuracy: Difference between grid data totals (integers) and totals from official statistics ranges from 10 to 1146 people based on country
Completeness: Dataset has no blank/missing values.
Creator: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Publisher: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Terms of use: Users may freely copy, publish and distribute the GEOSTAT 2011 grid dataset within their own organisation.
Other relevant information: The different, specific licencensing conditions for: GEOSTAT, Clusters, DEGURBA https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/gisco/geodata/reference-data/population-distribution-demography

Description (in brief): Heating and cooling degree days (monthly and annual).
Methodology (brief description): Heating Degree Days (HDD) index:  the severity of the cold in a specific time period taking into consideration outdoor temperature and average room temperature (in other words the need for heating). The calculation of HDD relies on the base temperature, defined as the lowest daily mean air temperature not leading to indoor heating. The value of the base temperature depends in principle on several factors associated with the building and the surrounding environment. By using a general climatological approach, the base temperature is set to a constant value of 15°C in the HDD calculation. Cooling degree days (CDD) index:  the severity of the heat in a specific time period taking into consideration outdoor temperature and average room temperature (in other words the need for cooling). The calculation of CDD relies on the base temperature, defined as the highest daily mean air temperature not leading to indoor cooling. The value of the base temperature depends in principle on several factors associated with the building and the surrounding environment. By using a general climatological approach, the base temperature is set to a constant value of 24°C in the CDD calculation. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Completeness: Dataset has no blank/missing values.
Creator: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Object: Cooling and heating degree days by country - annual data
Publisher: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)

Title (with Hyperlink): COMBI: Annualised net present value of energy efficiency improvement actions
Description (in brief): COMBI provides estimates of the major multiple impacts of the energy efficiency potential that goes beyond an existing policies scenario in the year 2030. Impacts are quantified by EU member state and by single energy efficiency improvement (EEI) action. Therefore, detailed input data on energy savings and investment costs are necessary: COMBI uses detailed stock models to this end. The COMBI input data modelling exercise produced a baseline scenario (based on existing EU legislation) and an efficiency scenario (based on ambitious assumptions on technology implementation following more ambitious policies), resembling the EUCO+33 scenario of the EU EED impact assessment.
Methodology (brief description): Annualised net value of actions were calculated based on selected actions and countries, annualised investments (annuisation based on selected discount rate), and selected annual impacts. Negative values imply costs of energy efficiency improvement (EEI) actions, positive values gains of EEI actions.
Completeness: Dataset has no blank/missing values
Creator: Thema, Johannes; Thomas, Stefan; Teubler, Jens; Chatterjee, Souran; Bouzarovski, Stefan; Mzavanadze, Nora; Suerkemper, Felix; Couder, Johan; Ürge-Vorsatz, Diana; von Below, David

Title (with Hyperlink): SETIS: Private R&I investment in energy technologies
Description (in brief): Integrated Strategic Energy Technology Plan Communication for each Member State on the level of investment in R&I from the private sector (expenditure by businesses and industry).
Methodology (brief description):
The technology coverage follows the integrated SET Plan structure, showing the links between the Energy Union R&I and Competitiveness priorities, the SET Plan Integrated Roadmap and the 10 SET Plan actions.
Trends in patents: The data source is PATSTAT, the Worldwide Patent Statistical Database created and maintained by the European Patent Office (EPO).
Private R&I investments: Data are estimated based on financial information from publicly available company statements and patent data from PATSTAT.
Public (national) R&I investments: The International Energy Agency (IEA) statistics are the main source of data. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Accuracy:
"The SETIS estimations of private R&I are a metric aimed
at enabling relative comparisons over time, rather than an accurate account of private
investment figures"
Completeness: Numerous missing  values
Creator: Pasimeni, Francesco; Fiorini, Alessandro; Georgakaki, Aliki; Marmier, Alain; Jimenez Navarro, Juan Pablo; Asensio Bermejo, Jose Miguel (Joint Research Centre)
Object: Private research and innovation (R&I) investment in energy technologies
Content (keywords): Research and innovation (R&I) - investment - energy technology
Origin: Joint Research Centre "Monitoring R&I in Low-Carbon Energy Technologies"

Title (with Hyperlink): CORDIS EU research projects under Horizon 2020
Description (in brief): This dataset contains projects and related organisations funded by the European Union under the Horizon 2020 framework programme for research and innovation from 2014 to 2020.
Methodology (brief description): Information from projects and related organisations funded by the European Union under the Horizon 2020 framework programme for research and innovation are collected and amalgamated monthly.
Completeness: Certain fields have missing values
Creator: European Commission
Object: CORDIS - EU research projects under Horizon 2020 (2014-2020)
Origin: Community Research and Development Information Service (CORDIS)

Description (in brief): Summary country RD&D budgets containing total public energy RD&D expenditure data from the IEA’s Energy Technology RD&D Budget Database.
Methodology (brief description): Budgets are collected through questionnaires and surveys issued by the International Energy Agency to nations.
Creator: International Energy Agency (IEA)
Other relevant information: Guest login for IEA Online Data Services Payment System, no information or payment information needed

Description (in brief): 71 core and non-core climate extreme indices (CEIs) based on the Expert Team on Climate Change Detection and Indices (ETCCDI), and the Expert Team on Sector-specific Climate Indices (ET-SCI).
Creator: Mistry, M.N.

Title (with Hyperlink): Copernicus: hourly global climate and weather data
Description (in brief): Data containing single-level climate and weather data (subset of the ERA5 reanalysis dataset).
Creator: Hersbach, H., Bell, B., Berrisford, P., Biavati, G., Horányi, A., Muñoz Sabater, J., Nicolas, J., Peubey, C., Radu, R., Rozum, I., Schepers, D., Simmons, A., Soci, C., Dee, D., Thépaut, J-N.
Object: ERA5 hourly data on single levels from 1979 to present
Content (keywords): Wind speed - precipitation - solar irradiance - air temperature
Origin: European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) ERA5 reanalysis data
Other relevant information: Free account required. For further information on use of dataset please visit https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/api/v2/terms/static/licence-to-use-copernicus-products.pdf

Description (in brief): High resolution renewable energy generation time series data of wind power capacity factors at NUTS 2 level.
Methodology (brief description): Total Full Load Hours (FLH) were calculated using the ratio between the sums of the energy produced (GWh) and the maximum possible generation (installed capacity(GW)*8760h (GWh)) per country. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Accuracy: As opposed to the IRENA dataset, Renewable.ninja dataset, and the Global Wind Atlas, EMHIRES takes into account wind farm specific power curves for each location which increases its accuracy versus the other datasets.
Completeness: Certain datasets from which this dataset was derived contained missing values, which were either completed with gap filling or certain datapoints were removed to create a complete dataset.
Level: EU27 + UK plus Iceland, Balkans countries
Creator: GONZALEZ APARICIO Iratxe; ZUCKER Andreas; CARERI Francesco; MONFORTI Fabio; HULD Thomas; BADGER Jake (Joint Research Centre)
Object: 30 years of wind power capacity factors at NUTS 2 level

Description (in brief): High resolution renewable energy generation time series data of solar power capacity factors at NUTS 2 level.
Methodology (brief description): Capacity factors were calculated from the ratio between the sums of the energy produced (GWh) and the maximum possible generation (installed capacity (GW)*8760) per country. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Accuracy: The validation of EMHIRES against power system statistics and time series published by Transmission System Operators shows a very good performance over the countries analysed. EMHIRES is able to capture the variability of solar energy, the seasonality and diurnal cycles and also the peaks and ramps. There is a general slight overestimation of the simulations due to the uncertainties accumulated in the theoretical process of the conversion of radiation into generation.
Completeness: Missing data from derived datasets (i.e. CM-SAF SARAH) were reconstructed to create a complete dataset.
Creator: GONZALEZ-APARICIO Iratxe, HULD Thomas, CARERI Francesco, MONFORTI Fabio, ZUCKER Andreas (Joint Research Centre)
Object: 30 years of hourly solar power capacity factors at NUTS 2 level

Description (in brief): The Global Tracking Framework measures the national energy intensities and the compound annual growth rate for all countries from 1990-2014.
Methodology (brief description): SE4ALL Global Tracking Framework for energy efficiency will: Rely primarily on energy intensity indicators; Use PPP measures for GDP and sectoral value-added; Use primary energy supply for national indicators and final energy consumption for sectoral indicators; Complement those indicators with energy intensity of supply and of the major demand sectors; Provide a decomposition analysis to at least partially strip out confounding effects on energy intensity; Use a five-year moving average for energy intensity trends to smooth out extraneous fluctuations. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Completeness: Missing values in 16.3% of cells
Creator: Global Tracking Framework

Description (in brief): Timeseries 1970–2018 of CO_ emissions by country and sector (Buildings, Power Industry, Transport, Other industrial combustion, Other sectors) in Mt CO_/year.
Methodology (brief description): In EDGAR, emissions per country and compound are calculated on an annual basis and sector wise by multiplying the country-specific activity and technology mix data by country-specific emission factors and reduction factors for installed abatement system for each sector. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Creator: Crippa, M., Oreggioni, G., Guizzardi, D., Muntean, M., Schaaf, E., Lo Vullo, E., Solazzo, E., Monforti-Ferrario, F., Olivier, J.G.J., Vignati, E. (Joint Research Centre)
Object: Data Package with EDGAR CO_ emissions

Description (in brief): Data containing pressure levels data (subset of the ERA5 reanalysis dataset).
Creator: Hersbach, H., Bell, B., Berrisford, P., Biavati, G., Horányi, A., Muñoz Sabater, J., Nicolas, J., Peubey, C., Radu, R., Rozum, I., Schepers, D., Simmons, A., Soci, C., Dee, D., Thépaut, J-N.
Object: ERA5 hourly data on pressure levels from 1979 to present

Description (in brief): The EU Digital Elevation Model (EU-DEM) combines data from different sources into a single consistent and homogeneous elevation dataset.
Level: Albania, Austria, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czechia, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Kosovo, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Montenegro, Netherlands, North Macedonia, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, United Kingdom
Creator: European Environment Agency

Description (in brief): This dataset covers indicators for monitoring progress towards energy efficiency targets of Europe 2020 strategy implemented by Directive 2012/27/EU on energy efficiency.
Methodology (brief description): The energy efficiency indicators are derived from energy balances, which are  obtained when you convert the natural units in the commodity balances to the chosen energy unit by multiplying by the appropriate conversion equivalent for each of the natural units. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Creator: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Publisher: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)

Title (with Hyperlink): Projected fresh water use from the European energy sector
Description (in brief): The dataset contains projections of fresh water withdrawal and consumption from the European energy sector on NUTS2 level by 2050 following EU Energy Reference Scenario 2016.
Methodology (brief description): The projected water used by the energy system is based on the combination of the EU Energy Reference Scenario with water withdrawal and consumption factors for the different processes considered throughout the report. These water factors were gathered from a broad literature review. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Accuracy: Compared to Eurostat estimates, Joint Research Centre estimates are within the reported range for most countries (discrepancies for Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, and Greece)
Completeness: Dataset has no blank/missing values
Creator: Medarac, H., Magagna, D. and Hidalgo González, I. (Joint Research Centre)
Object: Projected fresh water use from the European energy sector on NUTS2 level by 2050 following EU Energy Reference Scenario 2016
Content (keywords): Water withdrawal - water consumption - water use - energy production
Origin: "Projected fresh water use from the European energy sector" by the Joint Research Centre

Description (in brief): Photovoltaic power potential for Europe.
Methodology (brief description): The location-specific information provided by the Atlas involves three main different models: Solar radiation model; Air temperature model; PV power simulation model. Solar radiation and air temperature modeling result in a series of pre-calculated data layers that can be retrieved at (almost) any location on the map. Additional information about a possible PV system type and configuration are used for the PV power simulation, which is calculated on-demand using Solargis internal algorithms and databases. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Accuracy: "In most situations the expected uncertainty for annual values will be within ±4% for Global Horizontal Irradiance (GHI) values and ±9% for Direct Normal Irradiance (DNI) values for most of Europe and North America (approx. below 50°N) and Japan."
Completeness: "Missing records are very rare in the modern satellite and model data inputs. Intelligent gapfilling algorithms are used for gap filling. Historical satellite missions show higher percentage of missing or incorrect data records."
Creator: Betak, Juraj; Caltik, Marek; Cebecauer, Tomas; Chrkavy, Daniel; Erdelyi, Branislav; Rosina, Konstantin; Suri, Marcel; Suriova, Nada
Publisher: The World Bank Group and Solargis

Description (in brief): Wind power density by height for Europe.
Accuracy: Averaged Normalised Mean Biased Error[%] of Weather, Research and Forecasting (WRF) model experiments on long-term mean wind speed at four sites: 2%-15%
Completeness: Complete satellite data coverage for Europe
Creator: European Commission and 9 national funding agencies
Origin: New European Wind Atlas project from European Commission and 9 national funding agencies
Geographical extension: EU27 + UK, Turkey, and 100 km offshore as well as the complete North and Baltic Seas

Description (in brief): This dataset contains building stock analysis data for EU28. Data is available per country and are organized by residential and service sectors, addressing specific types of buildings and time periods.
Methodology (brief description): The data collected in the building stock analysis are used as starting point to calculate the useful energy demand (UED) for space heating (SH), space cooling (SC), and domestic hot water (DHW) for each EU28 MS down to its local level, and to derive scenarios for the future development of the UED.
Completeness: Incomplete source data was reconstructed by "extrapolating and assembling data from large data tools" and "researching data sourceby-source from single scientific literature fonts as journal papers, conference proceedings and project deliverables"
Creator: Simon Pezzutto, Silvia Croce, Stefano Zambotti, EURAC
Time references (time data refers): The majority of data refer to the year 2016
Content (keywords): Building characteristics - Building surface volume ratio

Title (with Hyperlink): H2020 SET-Nav: Detailed scenario results for energy demand by the INVERT/EE-Lab model
Description (in brief): Strategic Energy Roadmap datasets containing scenario data for energy demand.
Methodology (brief description): The core of the tool is a nested logit approach, which optimizes objectives of “agents” under imperfect information conditions and by that represents the decisions maker concerning building related decisions. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Completeness: Missing values in 9.7% of cells
Creator: SET-Nav consortium
Temporal Granularity: For year 2012, and then 2015 to 2050 in 5-year intervals
Content (keywords): Modelling Portofolio - Modelling Forum - Evaluation of energy policies - Stakeholder dialogue and dissemination

Title (with Hyperlink): Fuel consumption and technologies used in the heating/cooling sector
Description (in brief): These are the final results of a study of fuel consumption and technologies used in the heating/cooling sector in EU28+3 (Tender ENER/C2/2014-641). Analysis of scenarios up to 2020 and 2030 and a related economic analysis were also carried out together with the identification of obstacles, best practices and policy recommendations.
Level: EU27 + UK plus Norway, Switzerland, and Iceland
Creator: Authors of ENER/C2/2014-641 tender
Object: Mapping and analyses of the current and future (2020 - 2030) heating/cooling fuel deployment (fossil/renewables)

Geographical extension: EU27 + UK plus Norway, Switzerland, and Iceland

Description (in brief): The EPISCOPE project focused on the energy refurbishment of houses in 20 European countries. Among the collected information, data regarding the construction period (different classes are defined in each country) and the building type (single-family, terraced house, multi-family house and apartment block) may be useful for risk assessment of large geographic areas.
Accuracy: According to the EPISCOPE Synthesis Report SR4, quality data was not available for all countries. The accuracy of the data used may be varied based on how the data was obtained.
Completeness: Datasets have no blank/missing values. EPISCOPE Synthesis Report SR4 describes the lack of empirical primary data, including the "wide information gaps concerning the actual state as well as the trends of building thermal insulation and efficient / renewable heating systems"

Title (with Hyperlink): National Housing Census: type of living quarter by country
Description (in brief): The National Housing Census contains socioeconomic data as well as building stock data including type and size of housing
Methodology (brief description): Data in the National Housing Census are taken from national sources which use a variety of techniques to gather data (i.e. surveys).
Completeness: Missing values in <0.5% of cells (for type of living quarter by country)
Creator: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Publisher: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)

Description (in brief): This dataset shows the final energy demand for heating and hot water of buildings in EU28 on hectare (ha) level.
Creator: Andreas Mueller, Mostafa Fallahnejad, TU Wien Institute of Energy Systems and Electrical Drives
Object: Heat density map (final energy demand for heating and DHW) of buildings in EU28 + Switzerland, Norway and Iceland for the year 2015

Title (with Hyperlink): ECHOES: International survey on energy-related choices and behaviour
Description (in brief): ECHOES stands for “Energy CHOices supporting the Energy Union and the SET-Plan”. It is an EU funded research project that provides deeper understanding on individual and collective energy-related choices and behaviour. The international survey of the ECHOES project is a large survey dataset than contains responses from 31 countries: EU-28 (2018) + 3 countries.
Creator: Reichl, Johannes; Cohen, Jed; Kollmann, Andrea; Azarova, Valeria; Klöckner, Christian; Royrvik, Jens; Vesely, Stepan; Carrus, Giuseppe; Panno, Angelo; Tiberio, Lorenza; Fritsche, Immo; Masson, Torsten; Chokrai, Parissa; Lettmayer, Gudrun; Schwarzinger, Stephan; Bird, Neil, ECHOES project
Object: International survey of the ECHOES project

Title (with Hyperlink): HotMaps: Heated gross floor area density
Description (in brief): This dataset shows the residential and non-residential gross floor area in EU28 on hectare (ha) level.
Creator: Andreas Mueller, TU Wien Institute of Energy Systems and Electrical Drives
Object: Heated gross floor area density map of buildings in EU28 + Switzerland, Norway and Iceland for the year 2015
Content (keywords): Building stock - gross floor area density

Description (in brief): This dataset presents trends in man-made emissions of major greenhouse gases and emissions by gas.
Methodology (brief description): The data is derived from the National Inventory Submissions 2020  to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC, CRF tables), and replies to the OECD State of the Environment Questionnaire.
Creator: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)
Object: National Inventory Submissions 2019  to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
Publisher: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)
Origin: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

Description (in brief): Electricity prices for household consumers - bi-annual data (from 2007 onwards)
Methodology (brief description): Electricity prices are collected by a half-yearly questionnaire on electricity prices for households. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Accuracy: (For 2007 and onward data) the published prices are based on real invoiced prices that are paid by end-users
Completeness: For cost of electrical energy per kWh in Euros: missing data in 4.3% of cells
Level: EU27 + UK plus Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Albania, Serbia, Turkey, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Moldova, Ukraine, Georgia
Creator: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Object: Electricity prices for household consumers - bi-annual data (from 2007 onwards)
Publisher: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Geographical extension: EU27 + UK plus Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Albania, Serbia, Turkey, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Moldova, Ukraine, Georgia

Description (in brief): Mean consumption expenditure per household on electricity, gas, and other fuels.
Methodology (brief description): In summary the key concepts captured by the national accounts main aggregates datasets cover the following definitions: GDP - Gross domestic product. GDP at market prices is the final result of the production activity of resident producer units  It is defined in three ways: 1. GDP Output approach; 2. GDP Expenditure approach; 3. GDP Income approach.
Completeness: For current prices: missing data in 9.5% of cells
Level: EU27 + UK plus Iceland, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Norway, Switzerland, Albania, Serbia, Turkey, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Kosovo
Creator: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Object: Final consumption expenditure of households by consumption purpose (COICOP 3 digit)
Publisher: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Geographical extension: EU27 + UK plus Iceland, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Norway, Switzerland, Albania, Serbia, Turkey, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Kosovo

Description (in brief): The indicator shows the extent to which an economy relies upon imports in order to meet its energy needs. It is calculated as net imports divided by the gross available energy.
Methodology (brief description): Various statistical techniques are used to measure household energy use and energy dependence, including: business surveys, households surveys, use of administrative data, modelling, and in situ measurements. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Accuracy: "Quantitative assessment of accuracy was not performed by Eurostat"
Completeness: Missing values in 3.3% of cells
Level: EU27 + UK plus Iceland, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Norway, Albania, Serbia, Turkey, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Kosovo
Creator: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Publisher: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Content (keywords): Energy imports - net imports - gross available energy
Geographical extension: EU27 + UK plus Iceland, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Norway, Albania, Serbia, Turkey, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Kosovo

Description (in brief): GDP expressed in PPS (purchasing power standards) eliminates differences in price levels between countries. Calculations on a per inhabitant basis allow for the comparison of economies and regions significantly different in absolute size. GDP per inhabitant in PPS is the key variable for determining the eligibility of NUTS 2 regions in the framework of the European Union's structural policy.
Methodology (brief description): Regional GDP is valued at market prices by adding the regionalised taxes less subsidies on products and imports, and the Value Added Tax (VAT), to regional gross value added (GVA) at basic prices. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Completeness: Missing values in 6.6% of cells
Creator: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Object: Regional gross domestic product (million PPS) by NUTS 2 regions
Publisher: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Content (keywords): Gross domestic product - economic statistics - regional statistics
